title: Charles Leclerc insists Ferrari stance is 'clear now' after Russia Grand Prix farce
text:
Charles Leclerc says Ferrari's team orders are 'clear now' and claims it was a 'misunderstanding' that led to Sebastian Vettel disobeying them in last month's Russian Grand Prix.

Vettel reneged on a pre-race agreement to swap positions with his team-mate after taking the lead early on.

'There was some misunderstanding from the car but I think we've had a discussion and everything is clear now,' Leclerc said on Crash.net.

Charles Leclerc (Right) insists Ferrari orders for him and Sebastian Vettel are 'clear now'

Vettel refused to give Leclerc back the lead during the Russian Grand Prix last month

'Obviously it felt like it was a huge deal from the outside, which it definitely wasn't but now everything is fine.

'I think it's clear from the beginning of the season that we need to obey team orders, and what is clear is that the situation wasn't clear for both of the drivers at the start of the race.

'That is the most important thing and we will make sure that this situation doesn't happen again in the future.'

Ferrari boss Mattia Binotto has warned his two drivers that he wants no repeat of the Sochi farce in Japan, and has told Vettel and Leclerc they must be 'perfect'.

Both Ferrari drivers have been informed that they must be 'perfect' when racing in Japan

'Our performance level was good in Sochi, which is how we managed to take our fourth straight pole position, but we know that in order to be at the front in Japan, every aspect of our work must be perfect,' he told F1i.

'That's the way we are going to approach the race in Suzuka, trying to extract all the available performance from the car package.

'If we can do that, then we hope to be able to be as competitive as we have been in recent races.'
description: Charles Leclerc says Ferrari's team orders are 'clear now' and claims it was a 'misunderstanding' that led to Sebastian Vettel disobeying them in last month's Russian Grand Prix.
